statement.text: The Rutherford classification categorizes peripheral arterial disease into 7 grades (0-6) based on clinical symptoms and objective findings. It divides PAD into asymptomatic, claudication (mild/moderate/severe), ischemic rest pain, and tissue loss (minor/major). Unlike Fontaine, it uses objective testing (ABI, pulse volume recordings) to assign grades.
statement.formal: Rutherford Classification: Grade 0 = Asymptomatic | 1-3 = Claudication (mild, moderate, severe) | 4 = Rest pain | 5 = Minor tissue loss | 6 = Major tissue loss | Objective criteria include ABI, PVR, and functional testing

explanation.intuition: Rutherford is like a more detailed version of Fontaine, with clearer definitions and objective testing. Fontaine uses Roman numerals and symptom descriptions; Rutherford uses numbers 0-6 and adds objective measurements. Both tell the same story - from no symptoms through claudication to rest pain to tissue loss - but Rutherford is more precise and reproducible.
explanation.key_insight: The key difference from Fontaine is objectivity. Rutherford requires hemodynamic testing (ABI, pulse volume recordings) and functional testing (treadmill) to assign grades. This makes it more reproducible across centers and more useful for research. In clinical practice, you'll often see both systems used interchangeably.
explanation.technical_details: The classification was originally published by Rutherford et al. in 1986 and revised in 1997. Objective criteria: Grade 1 = mild claudication, ABI â‰¥0.80, treadmill >5 min at 2 mph/12% grade; Grade 2 = moderate, ABI 0.50-0.80, treadmill 1-5 min; Grade 3 = severe, ABI <0.50, treadmill <1 min; Grade 4 = rest pain, ankle pressure <40 mmHg, toe pressure <30 mmHg; Grades 5-6 = tissue loss with same hemodynamic criteria. The Society for Vascular Surgery now prefers the WIfI classification for critical limb ischemia staging.
common_misconceptions: Rutherford and Fontaine are interchangeable - they differ in criteria and objectivity
Claudication grades are based on walking distance alone - ABI also required
Rutherford replaces Fontaine - both are used, Fontaine in Europe, Rutherford in US
Higher Rutherford grade = worse amputation risk - WIfI is better for prognosis

definitions_glossary.rutherford_classification: Seven-grade system for PAD severity using objective criteria
definitions_glossary.fontaine_classification: Four-stage system for PAD using clinical symptoms
definitions_glossary.pulse_volume_recording: Measurement of volume changes in limb with each heartbeat
definitions_glossary.treadmill_test: Standardized walking test to assess claudication severity
definitions_glossary.wifi_classification: Wound, Ischemia, foot Infection staging for CLTI

classification_grades.description: No symptoms, abnormal ABI or hemodynamics
Able to complete treadmill test; walk >5 min at 2 mph, 12% grade
classification_grades.clinical_findings: Claudication that doesn't significantly limit daily activities

classification_grades.description: Unable to complete treadmill test; walk <1 min at 2 mph, 12% grade
Chronic ischemic pain at rest >2 weeks
classification_grades.hemodynamic_criteria: Ankle pressure <40 mmHg, toe pressure <30 mmHg, flat PVR

classification_grades.description: Nonhealing ulcer or focal gangrene with diffuse pedal ischemia

clinical_application.research: Preferred for clinical trials due to objective criteria
clinical_application.replaced_by_wifi: For CLTI, WIfI classification now preferred for prognosis

definition.@value: Seven-grade classification system for PAD severity using clinical and objective hemodynamic criteria

sources.citation: Rutherford RB, et al. Recommended standards for reports dealing with lower extremity ischemia. J Vasc Surg. 1997;26:517-538.

learning_objectives: Explain the objective criteria for each grade
Understand when to use each classification system
clinical_pearls: Rutherford uses numbers 0-6, Fontaine uses Roman numerals I-IV
For CLTI prognosis, WIfI classification is now preferred
